elements.title: Storm Ulysses (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Storm Ulysses (damage pictured) in 1903 was so named because its effects were described in James Joyce's novel Ulysses?

elements.title: Tamurbek Dawletschin (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Tamurbek Dawletschin wrote one of the few memoirs by a Soviet prisoner of war, 3 million of whom died in German captivity?

elements.title: Car Thing (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a class-action lawsuit was filed against Spotify following the discontinuation of the Car Thing?

elements.title: David Yong (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Singaporean former lawyer David Yong learned Korean and moved to South Korea to become a K-pop singer?

elements.title: AMES Type 6 (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that during the Tunisian campaign in World War II, crews carried an AMES Type 6 radar set across a swamp to allow them to spy on Luftwaffe aircraft running supplies into Tunis?

elements.title: Gwent Broadcasting (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Gwent Broadcasting, at the time the smallest Independent Local Radio station in Britain, lasted less than two years?

elements.title: Valentin Bontus (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Valentin Bontus won the first-ever Olympic gold medal in Formula Kite, while Toni Vodišek won the first silver medal?

elements.title: Khalji Revolution (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that during the Khalji Revolution, Sultan Qaiqabad was wrapped in a carpet and thrown into the Yamuna river?

elements.title: Poecilia vandepolli (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the small fish species Poecilia vandepolli solves food shortage problems by eating its own offspring?
